message_1:
Here's a precise numerical problem for the student to solve in propositional logic:

Let p be the statement "I will eat breakfast," and let q be the statement "I will have coffee." Write the truth table for the proposition "if I don't eat breakfast, then I won't have coffee."
message_2:
To write the truth table for the proposition "if I don't eat breakfast, then I won't have coffee," we first need to represent this proposition in propositional logic. The proposition can be written as "if ¬p, then ¬q" or equivalently, "¬p → ¬q".

The truth table for this proposition is as follows:

| p | q | ¬p | ¬q | ¬p → ¬q |
|---|---|----|----|---------|
| T | T | F  | F  | T       |
| T | F | F  | T  | T       |
| F | T | T  | F  | F       |
| F | F | T  | T  | T       |

Here, T represents True and F represents False.
